field_edited_text.value:
Opening day, Harborplace, 1980



was loaned to the owners of the Hyatt
chain. The City constructed a $4 million
parking garage. In return, the hotel is to
repay the city loan at seven percent and
pay a base ground rent, plus 2/3’s of the
hotel’s profits to the City. The City leased
the land on which the Baltimore Hyatt
stands for 34 years, with an option to
extend for 20 additional years. The hotel
also pays its full share of property taxes.
These terms, which reduced the private risk
capital to $4 million of a total package of
over $37.5 million, has proven to be a good
investment for all concerned. The Balti-
more Hyatt is one of the most successful in
the entire chain and the hotel"is now seek-
ing to buy out the City’s interest. Hundreds
of city residents have been employed, and
an important drawing card has been pro-
vided for Convention Center business.

More than 10 years after the initial re-
development activity began, the Rouse
Company came forward with a proposal to
erect the shopping component of the Inner
Harbor plan, two pavilions of shops and
restaurants along the Inner Harbor prome-
nade. The proposal which was-unveiled in
1978 was called Harborplace. While gener-
ally well received there were mixed reac-
tions to the proposal.

A sizable segment of the public op-
posed any commercial use of what had
come to be viewed as “their’” open space.
Others opposed the loss of valuable open
space they had come to enjoy at the
water’s edge. Some opposition came from
the Black community which felt it might be
frozen out of high-priced shops and restau-
rants. Several owners of shops and restau-
rants in South Baltimore and Little Italy
feared their businesses would suffer.

Although city plans had always called
for commercial use along the shoreline of
the Inner Harbor, the reality of the Rouse
plan galvanized opponents. As the former
chairman of the City Planning Commission
put it, “Baltimoreans are so pleased with
the first phase of their Inner Harbor that
they fear, if it is completed as originally
planned, they won’t be pleased.” To
address the opposition, private citizens’
groups and the Rouse Co. worked to pre-
sent the favorable aspects of the plan, pro-
viding extensive efforts to include minority
firms, significant minority hiring, high tax
returns and careful attention to design.

With the backing of the city, business
community and many citizens groups, the
referendum on Harborplace in 1978 passed
with 54 percent of the vote. Since that turn-
ing point, many of those in opposition
have come to express support for the way
Harborplace has turned out. As part of the
referendum, 26 acres around the harbor
basin are to remain forever as public park
space.





On July 2, 1980 Harborplace opened to
a noontime crowd of over 50,000. For the
city Harborplace has turned out to be a
bonanza many times over, from the reve-
nues that have poured forth from the 18
million visits to the 140 shops and stands in
their first year of operation, the worldwide
publicity that has followed the spectacular
success of Harborplace and the Inner Har-
bor redevelopment in general, and the use
of pavilions and promenade as the city’s
modern-day boardwalk.



Opening day Harborplace, 1980

Maryland Port Administration



Peter Solmmsen
